intro: Tapeinosperma papuanum, commonly known as the Papuan tamarind, is a tropical tree native to New Guinea. It belongs to the family Rhamnaceae and is characterized by its compound leaves and small, yellowish flowers. The plant produces oval, woody pods that contain several seeds surrounded by a sticky, resinous pulp. It is often found in lowland and hill forest areas, thriving in humid, well-drained soils. The species is valued for its hard wood and has some traditional uses in local communities.
